title: dont surprised report nusrat ghani
story: Don’t be surprisedreport into Nusrat Ghani ‘Muslimness sacking is a whitewashNusrat Ghani says she was sacked in  because her ‘Muslimness’ Image: Chris McAndrew   UK Parliament opinionByDarren Lewis:,  Jan As a reporter on my local paper, I took a call from a Tory councillor. It was during the Nineties and he was a governor at a nearby school. We arranged to meet to discuss a story. My paper didn’t have picture bylines at the time but I knew who he was. We arranged to meet at a town hall but as I approached him a look of horror swept over his face. I stuck out a hand to introduce myself.“Hi, I’m Darren, good to meet you.” I said. “Oh,” he replied. “You don’t sound black on the phone ”The meeting didn’t last long.  I remembered it while listening to the preposterous Tory MP Michael Fabricant over the weekend. He was speaking after ex-minister Nusrat Ghani claimed she was told by party Whips that she was sacked in  because her ‘Muslimness’ made colleagues uncomfortable. Chief Whip Mark Spencer has rejected the claim as “completely ” and “defamatory”. Fabricant took to radio station LBC, saying: “I think the whole thing actually stinks. She’s hardly someone who is obviously a Muslim.”  Where to start  To dismiss blond wig-on-a-stick Fabricant as a ludicrous character Harry Enfield or Ricky Gervais would have been proud of actually allows the Lichfield MP off the hook. You can make up your own mind as to the legitimacy of Ms Ghani’s claim. It wouldn’t surprise anyone, however, that it has erupted within a party whose leader compared Muslim women to letterboxes and bank robbers. Or that Downing Street has confirmed Ms Ghani complained to Prime Minister Boris Johnson directly – two years ago.  Johnson, she claimed, urged the former junior minister to use the formal complaint process which, with this regime, is probably a bit like going to the policeyou have an issue with a colleague within the mafia. Don’t be fooled into thinking the inquiry called by Johnson on Monday morning is anything other than a welcome opportunity to keep the upcoming Partygate report from Sue Grayoff the front pages. If Johnson really does take the issue seriously, why didn’t he bang his fist on his desk and order the inquiry back then, when Ms Ghani told him  In any case the inquiry won’t be independent - even though civil servants are supposed to be. It will be conducted by the Cabinet Office – the people who work for the PM. Don’t be surprised when it turns up a nothing-to-see-here whitewash. The stag do that has been Johnson’s premiershiphas shown us a party stuck in the past. A nationalistic, flag-waving regime, replete with Benny Hill-type chancers pining for the days of the Empire and a time when you could say anything you wanted, regardless of any offence caused. It comes from the top. We shouldn’t be surprised it is rotten from the core. title: downtown abbey star peter egan
story: Downtown Abbey star Peter Egan backs High Court fight to ban disgusting chicken farmsPeter Egan, who plays Hugh MacClare in the period drama, filmed undercover in a farm where , chicks were being reared in a hangar and is now backing court action to have them outlawedDownton Abbey actor Peter Egan Image: Getty ImagesByRobin Eveleigh:,  Jan Downton Abbey actor Peter Egan was so appalled by the “disgusting” conditions at an industrialised chicken farm he is backing court action to have them outlawed. Last year the star, who plays Hugh MacClare in the period drama, filmed undercover in a farm where , chicks were being reared in a hangar. He said: “The moment the door was opened, the stench and the heat were overwhelming. The chicks were clearly in a state of terrible discomfort. “They had only been there two days and the floor was littered with dead bodies. “I felt so sorry for these little creatures. Everything about it was disgusting and I just felt that no cheap food was worth this.” Becoming a vegan in  Peter has thrown his weight behind the campaign, being led by pressure group Humane Being.  Their application for a judicial review of Defra’s support for factory farming is being heard in the High Court today. In court papers seen by the Mirror, Humane Being accuse Defra, headed by Environment Secretary George Eustice, of jeopardising public health by allowing “continued unsafe farming practices”. They cite scientists’ claims of links between pandemic diseases and factory farming. And they say Defra is flouting human rights laws by failing to protect the public against its dangers. Today’s hearing will decide whether Humane Being’s allegations can be heard in full before a High Court judge. Jane Tredgett, Humane Being founder, said: “Factory Farms pose a signicant risk for the outbreak of increasingly deadly zoonotic diseases like bird or swine flu, with the potential to kill millions of people around the world.” Peter added: “It’s not surprising that diseases are transmitted from these facilities. Animals are living in such close proximity that they become stressed, and their immune system collapses. “Corporations have decided factory farming is a great way of making money – at the expense of any compassion for the poor animal. “Profit is the motive, driven by the lie it’s producing good, cheap food for the masses. We have to actually own up to the fact that, here in the UK, we’re an animal-loving country in name only.  “So few people are prepared to go the extra mile in terms of care and compassion for animals. One of the steps is to say, we don’t need factory farming [or] animal products at every meal.” Defra said it does not comment on legal proceedings. However, a spokesman said: “We continue to promote the production of healthier, higher welfare farm animals. “All farms should implement strong biosecurity measures and report suspected disease immediately.”Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Peter EganDownton AbbeySwine fluHuman rightsImmune systemFluAnimals" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: expert gives cause mystery dog
story: Expert gives cause of mystery dog illness killing thousands of UK sea creaturesMarine biologist David McCreadie shared his views on the mysterious illness that is affecting hundreds of dogs and killing wildle along the coast of YorkshireMarine biology expert David McCreadie gives his opinion Image: David McCreadieByJoanne WelfordLaura SharmanFreelance writer:,  Jan | commentsA mysterious illness that is impacting dogs and killing thousands of sea creatures along the British coast has been explained by an expert. David McCreadie believes a process called dredging is behind the deadly illness which has had a devastating effect on wildle in recent months. Hundreds of pet pooches have reportedly been struck down after walks on beaches along Yorkshireaposs coast over the past few weeks. Meanwhile dead crabs and rotting lobsters have been littering the coastline between Marske and Saltburn in North Yorkshire, while piles of crustaceans have been spotted in Seaton Carew and Seaham in County Durham. Mr McCreadie said he saw a vessel dredging off Teesmouth near the North Yorkshire coast in late September.The former senior lecturer in marine biology and oceanography believes this process has released historic toxins from the bottom of the sea, reports Yorkshire Live.It comes after a fisherman reported that there are no crabs or fish for miles off Yorkshireaposs coast and that he has to survive off just £ a month.  Investigators have ruled out dredging as the cause behind these events but Mr McCreadie claims a two-week operation unearthed historic toxins off Teesmouth and the dredged material was dumped three or four miles off the coast. He has called for more samples to be taken by the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairsand for Government labs to test specically for cyanide and deadly dioxins. The expert, also a member of the British Divers Marine Le Rescue, has been keeping an eye on reports of dogs falling ill after walking on the beaches which some believe is linked to the piles of dead sea creatures washed up on the shores. Mr McCreadie said he is . per cent certain that the dredging operation unearthed toxins left behind from a century of dumping in the Tees river. In November , the Environment Agency rejected chemical pollution as a likely cause and investigators have said dredging, sewage and undersea cabling activity is not to blame either. More than , potential chemical contaminants have been screened and inspectors said no anomalies that could lead to an event of that scale have been found. Defra is now leading the investigation and said samples of dredged material had to meet high standards before it could be disposed of at sea. A spokesperson said Environment Agency tests on crabs and lobsters also ruled out chemical pollution. title: family finds scorpion snuck bags
story: Family finds scorpion had snuck into bags in Costa Rica  days after ing to UKThe stowaway scorpion was found in their kitchen in Winchester, Hants., after it snuck into one of the suitcases while they were traveling in Costa Rica and survived the -hour and -minute flight back to the UKA family were shocked to find this scorpion has snuck into their suitcase from Costa Rica Image: RSPCAByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Jan | commentsA family were shocked to find a scorpion had got in their luggage while they were in Costa Rica. To make things worse, they didnapost find the pincer-wielding arachnid for  days. The stowaway scorpion was found in their kitchen after it snuck into one of the suitcases they were in the Central American country. It miraciously survived the -hour and -minute flight back to the UK, but remained undetected for a week-and-a-half before the family spotted it and alerted the RSPCA. The creatures - which have venom in their sting tails - can kill humans. The family from Winchester, Hants., had been holidaying in Costa Rica which is , milesaway.  An RSPCA spokesperson said: This scorpion departed from Costa Rica and arrived at a house in Winchester. The shocked family found him in their kitchen  days after theyaposd ed from vacation Heaposs now safe and in expert care. One animal lover urged travelling Brits to check their belongings for hidden creatures when they pack to come home and said: Poor little thing, glad heaposs safe now. for our daily newsletter to keep up to date with all the essential information atwww.mirror email.Itaposs really not that dficult to check shoes and clothes when packing. Just allow a little more time for it is all, donapost leave it until the very last minute.Last year, a plane was forced to turn back mid-flight after a cat reportedly attacked the pilot.The Sudan to Qatar Tarco Airlines flight encountered a problem roughly  minutes into its journey. A cat, which is thought to have got aboard during cleaning, seemingly woke up during the flight and attacked crew members.  And in  , a woman ended up making two trips to France toa stowaway dormouse to its home. The rodent got in Dr Sue Collard’s car as she drove back from her holiday home in Normandy in April.Ten days later, she spotted it snfing some pears and caught it in a homemade trap, but it escaped. After recapturing it, she drove back to the hamlet of Saint-Gervais-des-Sablons last month but the dormouse would not budge. She then set off for France again earlier this month and finally had success after forking out £ on ferries and petrol. news uk-news five-signs-harrys-frosty-relationship-"Prince Harry files claim over police protection for familyByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Jan | comments After quitting the Firm and moving to America to start a new le, Prince Harry aposs relationships with some of the royals have been rocky. And the bond with his dad Prince Charles is one that has especially felt the strain of late. Last year, in his bombshell interview with Oprah Winfrey, Harry accused his dad of cutting him off financially and not taking his calls. In addition, Harry has also appeared on the Apple TV series The Me You Canapost See, where he spoke about the royalsapos total neglect and the Armchair Expert podcast, where he lashed out at Charlesaposs parenting. And just last month, one report claimed relations between the pair were at aposrock bottomapos and that they were barely speaking. However, with the turn of the year, there have been claims of several olive branches, which appear to show that their icy relationship may be starting to thaw... Fatheraposs pride One of the first signs that Harry and Charlesapos relationship could be improving was just days into the New Year. It came in an essay that Charles wrote for Newsweek, where he issued a call for urgent action to save the environment.In the piece, he praised both Prince William and Harry for their work in raising awareness of the issue.Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up.Months earlier, at her speech at the Cop climate change summit in Glasgow in November, the Queen name-checked both Charles and William for their work in saving the environment, but there was no mention of Harry. However, in the essay, Charles spoke about how he was proud of both William and Harry for having recognised the threat of climate change. He said: Most recently, my elder son, William, launched the prestigious Earthshot Prize to incentivise change and help repair our planet over the next ten years by identying and investing in the technologies that can make a dference. And my younger son, Harry, has passionately highlighted the impact of climate change, especially in relation to Africa, and committed his charity to being net-zero. Enjoyable video calls Shortly after the Newsweek essay was released, the Mirror revealed that Charles had held several “good-natured and enjoyable” video calls with Harry. Sources close to Charles said that despite reports of the two not speaking, Charles and Harry have been on “a journey of rediscovery” in terms of their relationship. One said: “The Prince of Wales has spoken to his son frequently in recent months. He loves him very much, as he does both his children, and he looks forward to them being able to spend time together in the near future.” Missing grandchildren And not only does it appear that Charles is missing his son and daughter-in-law Meghan, he is also desperate to see their children.Charles hasnapost seen two-year-old Archie since the family moved to Calornia and he is yet to meet his seven-month-old granddaughter Lilibet. One source said: “The Prince of Wales has been saddened that he hasn’t had the opportunity to spend time with his grandchildren, which he really does miss. “He is a fantastic grandfather and loves playing the role immensely and it’s certainly fair to say he feels there is something missing from his le without the ability to get to know Harry’s children. Invitation to stay Meanwhile, another olive branch Charles has extended to his youngest son is an invitation to stay with him when he and his family next visit the UK. The offer of bringing the family together for the first time since Harry and Meghan decided to quit their royal roles and set up home in Calornia was made by the heir in the lead up to Christmas, it is understood. But Charles’s good-natured plan, in an attempt to heal the rt between him and his son, has been thrown into doubt after Harry suggested awould come at “too great a personal risk” due to his security situation.  Harry claims he is “unable tohome” after a decision following his exit from the royal family stripped him of his right to personal security provided by the Met Police. He has since decided to sue the British government by applying for a judicial review against the decision, which could see him face the Home Office at the court.Meanwhile, a report today suggests Charlesapos invitation comes amid fears over what Harryaposs memoir, due out this year, will say about Camilla, the Duchess of Cornwall.Those fears are said to revolve around Harryaposs recollections of Camillaaposs entry into the Royal Family and how her romance with his father damaged him from a young age. Secret talksHowever, itaposs also said that Harry himself reached out to his dad with the pair having secret talks to heal their rt before the Queenaposs Platinum Jubilee celebrations. A royal insider told the Sun : “There has been a definite thaw in relations between Harry and Charles. They are on much better terms and have been having friendly chats and video calls.“It has been suggested to Harry he may live to regret any lingering family bitterness, and he has taken that on board. “There is a feeling he is coming back more into the fold and wants to be closer to his family.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Prince HarryPrince Charles, Prince of WalesRoyal Family" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: girl 14 dances way heaven
story: Girl, , dances her way to heaven as brave teen loses rare cancer battleLily Douglas, , from Perth in Scotland, has tragically died after a battle with a five-year battle with a rare and aggressive form of cancer called Ewing Sarcoma that attacks bone and its surrounding tissuesLily Douglas, , from Perth in Scotland, tragically passed away last night after a five-year battle with cancer Image: Jane DouglasByKathleen SpeirsReporterRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Jan | comments A brave teen hasdanced her way to heaven after her tragic death from a rare cancer, her heartbroken mum has said.Lily Douglas, , from Perth in Scotland, bravely battled Ewing Sarcoma - a rare form of cancer that attacks the bones and surrounding tissues - for five years. Her grief-stricken mum Jane shared the devastating news in a social media post yesterday.She was participating in a potential breakthrough drug trial at Newcastleaposs Royal Victoria Infirmary when she suffered a brain bleed and died, the Daily Record reports.After being admitted on January , doctors told Jane they were unsureLily would last the night. Butshe did survive, they didnapost know what damage would be done. Lily - who won the Teenager of Courage prize at the Pride of Scotland Awards - managed to open her eyes on Sunday and spoke with her mum, ate some food and even checked her phone for messages. But her condition worsened and she passed away at .pm last night, with her mum confirming she had danced her way to heaven.Announcing the tragic news on Facebook, Jane wrote: Her heart failed but she was on the sofa at home, cuddled into me where she wanted to be.She will leave a massive hole in my heart. If love could have saved her she would have lived to a million years old. She is at peace and is finally in no more pain. Even with cancer, Lily lived her best le and was loved by everyone. I hope I made her proud. I was her mum, we were a great team. Please keep Leon in your prayers, he will need lots of love and support. Itaposs not goodbye, she will be waiting on me. Itaposs only time that will keep us apart. She looks so beautul and peaceful and even died with her beautul, blonde hair. Thank you all for your love and support. I could not have done this without you all. Lilyaposs inspirational fight saw her scoop a Pride of Scotland Award last year where she was crowned Teenager of Courage. Her tenacity did not go unrecognised by a host of famous faces. Strictly Come Dancing icon Dame Arlene Phillips built a strong bond with the hero schoolgirl. Lilyaposs bravery even inspired the TV star to take part in last yearaposs Iaposm A Celebrity. . . Get Me Out Of Here! Arelene, , said on the show: One of the bravest, most fearless girls is a little girl I know called Lily Douglas, sheaposs so fearless. I thought, here I am afraid of so many things. What better way can you push yourself than to do something like this  Closer to home, Lewis Capaldi gave Lily aposthe best day of her leapos when he invited her on stage when he performed at TRNSMT in .The Someone You Loved singer sent a video message to Lily at an awards ceremony before striking up a friendship over Instagram. He invited her and pal Yasmin Chan to come meet him in the artist village backstage - where he surprised her with the chance of a letime to hang out side stage. The pair also wowed online followers when they took part in a popular TikTok challenge together. Gorgeous Lilyaposs talents didnapost end at dancing. In October last year she took to the catwalk, modelling prom dresses alongside Miss Scotland, Claudia Todd who hailed the teen as aposbeautul and talentedapos. Loved ones paid tribute to Lily in their droves hailing her as aposan amazing girl apos with aposa beautul heartapos. One said: Omg Jane, I am devastated for you, she was a beautul girl with a beautul heart. Another added: Jane I am so so heartbroken for your loss, she was such an amazing girl. A third said: Jane I am so so sorry. Lily was a beautul, special little girl and she touched so many lives. I am heartbroken for you all. Much love. title: inside prince andrews raunchy topless
story: Inside Prince Andrews raunchy topless holidays with infamous NyLon gangPrince Andrew was reportedly ordered by the Queen to dump his pals and their "murky world of cocaine, crime and casual sex" before he damaged the Monarchy foreverPrince Andrew on-board a yacht off the coast of Phuket in Thailand Image: Eliot Press   ELIOTPRESS   MEGAByDanya BazaraaSenior News ReporterRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Jan Prince Andrew was reportedly warned he must cut ties from a gang of friends amid fears for the royal reputation as he partied in nightclubs more than  years ago.A  article by the Sunday People told how Prince Andrew was ordered by the Queen to dump his pals and their murky world of cocaine, crime and casual sex before he damaged the Monarchy forever. It spoke of the Queen and Prince Philipaposs fury after Andrew was pictured with topless women and touring red-light districts on a holiday in Phuket, Thailand. The Sunday People at the time revealed the Duke of Yorkaposs new friends were nicknamed the NyLon Gang because they went between New York and London with no expense spared.  Among the people in the gang was Ghislaine Maxwell, who it was said took Prince Andrew to nightclubs and parties.An insider told the Sunday People back in : Andrew has been told in no uncertain terms that he must cut loose from this gang with all their drug links before it drags the reputation of the Royals into the mire. His behaviour is not that expected of the Duke of York and he has been told it must end right now. Andrew is laying himself open to exploitation and scandal and is becoming an appalling liability. What sort of example does he set to the rest of the world  Reports have said Prince Andrew went on tours of red-light sex clubs with billionaire paedo Jeffrey Epstein and holidayed with pimp Ghislaine Maxwell while in Thailand. In a set of infamous photos, the Duke of York played up to his Playboy Prince moniker when he was seen surrounded by topless supermodels partying on a yacht off the coast of Thailand seaside resort, Phuket. Maxwell and Epstein were said to have been on the same holiday as Andrew, with the former thought to have stayed at his hotel. And the manager of a venue in Patongaposs red-light district said he was graced with a regal visit when the British prince visited the topless go-go bar. The wild holiday, which took place in New Year in , was around the time Prince Andrew became close with the couple - and just months before he allegedly sexually assaulted Virginia Giuffre.  Andrew has vehemently denied this allegation and claims there was nothing improper about his relationship with the couple - who were both convicted of child sex crimes in the US. The Duke of York splashed out £,-a-night on a private villa at the lavish and ultra-exclusive Amanpuri Hotel in Phuket - where the couple also stayed, reports say. A Phuket-based journalist known as Lana told The Sun Online the resort is the go-to place for high-profile figures who need a high level of luxury and privacy.Spending his days on yachts with scantily-clad women, by night the Prince reportedly teamed up with Epstein to visit Patong - a notorious sex tourism hub where the streets are lined with go-go bars, massage parlours and other adult entertainment venues.  The pair visited the Banana Disco - a popular tourist nightclub which advertises itself online with videos of women wearing not much at all. The Queenaposs second son was said to have repeatedly visited a bar called Crazy Girls by Rock Hard, which is in a raunchy area where many of the girls are prostitutes.On Facebook, it says punters can enjoy the craziest and sexiest ass-smacking bar.Speaking to The Sunday Mirror at the time, the manager said: I was amazed to see the Prince here. But he was not at all fazed and seemed quite relaxed until people realised who he was.Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Prince Andrew, Duke of YorkRoyal Family" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: lovely dad two year old
story: Lovely dad and two-year-old son die in horror three-car collisionJohn Woodcock, , of Sutton-in-Ashfield, known as Dan to his family and friends, and his two-year-old son Lewis died in hospital following the collision in Mansfield earlier this monthJohn Woodcock, , and his two-year-old son, Lewis Image: Nottinghamshire Police   SWNSByJake Brigstock:,  Jan | commentsPolice have named the father and his two-year-old son who died in a crash involving multiple vehicles in Nottinghamshire.John Woodcock, of Sutton-in-Ashfield, known as Dan to his family and friends, and his two-year-old son Lewis died in hospital following the collision on Chesterfield Road North in Mansfield.The crash happened close to the junction with Pleasley Hill just after .pm on Saturday, January . Three cars are believed to have been involved in the incident as police continue to investigate what happened. Mr Woodcock and Lewis had already been named locally, and colleagues of Mr Woodcock, who ran Herbieaposs Hemp, a planet friendly waste shop within the Idlewells Indoor Market Hall in Sutton-in-Ashfield, have paid tribute.  The -year-old has been described as a aposlovely person and lovely characterapos. A fundraising page set up to help cover funeral costs has already surpassed its target. Detective Inspector Clare Gibson, of Nottinghamshire Policeaposs Serious Collision Investigation Unit, said: Our thoughts are with their family who continue to be provided with support by specialist officers at this dficult time. We continue to investigate the full circumstances and our appeal for information remains. Anyone who witnessed the incident or who has dash-cam footage is urged to please get in touch. The driver of one of the other vehicles was also taken to hospital where he remains. His injuries are not currently believed to be le-threatening.Anyone with information is asked to call Nottinghamshire Police on , quoting incident  of January  .Alternatively, they can call Crimestoppers anonymously on   . title: man 22 who couldnt swim
story: Man, , who couldnt swim drowns in sea while bravely trying to save friendIn the early hours after a night out, Alex raced to the seafront in Blackpool and got into the water after a friend called him and told him she didnt want to live anymoreAlexs friends said he had enjoyed going to Stanley Park in Blackpool to feed the birdsByAmy Fenton:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsA brave man lost his le after drowning in the sea while attempting to save his friend who had gotten into trouble in the water. Alex Gibson, , had been on a night out with friends in Blackpool on Thursday, July  last year when the tragedy occurred. He had spent some time with his friend over the course of the evening but the pair separated when she went to Sapphires nightclub in the resort. In the early hours of Friday morning, Alexaposs friend called him from the North Pier and told him she didnapost want to live anymore. Alex raced to the seafront and went into the water to try and help her despite not being able to swim.An inquest at Blackpool Town Hall today heard that she got out and went for help but Alex was then found face down in the water less than an hour later, Lancs Live reported. Alex had met his friend while working at C Fresh Fish and Chips in Foxhall Road. Speaking at todayaposs inquest, she said: We were near the steps [to the right of the pier].  We were both in the water together. I was trying to help Alex because he couldnapost swim. We were hanging on to each other trying to keep each other afloat. I realised that the only way we were both getting out wassomeone got help so I told him that I was going to get out and get help. It took me a while to swim back because the current was really strong. After she managed to get out of the water she shouted back to Alex to tell him it would be okay. He was just trying to stay afloat, she said. I remember seeing him get further out. He was shouting for help. Mark Wright, who was sleeping rough in a shelter on the Promenade, said he was woken at .am when he heard Alexaposs friend screaming: Alex I canapost live without you. Giving evidence at the inquest, Mr Wright said he could see Alex struggling to keep his head above the water, but then lost sight of him because it was dark.  David Langton, who had also been asleep in a shelter, woke up when he heard Mark shouting to him: Get on your phone David thereaposs someone in the water. [Alexaposs friend] told me she wanted to kill herself, Mr Langton said in a statement. She told me her friend couldnapost swim. I tried to look for him but I couldnapost see anything. PC Ryan Kavanagh of Lancashire Police was driving down the Promenade at around .am on Friday, July  and pulled over when he saw Mr Wright at the side of the road. He asked meI was there because there was someone in the water, PC Kavanagh said.  I drove to the other side of the pier... below was [Alexaposs friend] near the wateraposs edge. She was covered in a blanket. She informed me she had been in the water, she didnapost want to be here anymore, and her friend had followed her to save her. She told me sheaposd kill herselfAlex was deceased. Leboat helmsman Sean Wright, who has volunteered with Blackpool RNLI for  years, was involved in the search for Alex. The crew spotted Alexaposs friendaposs white Primark handbag floating in the sea and  minutes later, at .am, found Alexaposs body face down in the water  metres from the shore. Alex was taken to Blackpool Victoria Hospital where resuscitation efforts continued but he was pronounced dead at .am. The medical cause of death was given as drowning with alcohol intoxication listed as a contributory factor. Dillon Dixon had known Bradford-born Alex for  years after the pair met at school and the two friends shared a house together. They had been out together on the Thursday night and Dillon had gone home at around pm. The following morning at .am, not knowing that his friend had just been declared dead, Dillon woke up and jokingly text Alex saying hope youaposre alive. Weaposve all jokingly sent similar after a night out, Dillon said.  The inquest heard Dillon, who had offered to take Alex to swimming lessons, thought of him as being like a brother and the two friends went through everything together. He was a proud vegan and had a heart of gold, Dillon said. He enjoyed going to Stanley Park to feed the birds. Alex has in the past had many dark thoughts and said he was tired of everything. He was always sad inside but had the biggest smile on his face. The inquest heard that although Alex had self-harmed in the weeks before his death and occasionally had dark moments there was no evidence he had deliberately taken his own le. Concluding that Alexaposs death was a result of misadventure - the unintended consequences of a deliberate act - Senior Coroner Alan Wilson said: Disregarding his own welfare, as someone who could not swim, this young man bravely went in the water and tried to save a vulnerable young girl. Anyone who has seen the tide at Blackpool when itaposs fully in knows it is dangerous. Itaposs most likely he got into dficulty pretty quickly and he was witnessed by someone trying to stay above the waterline. He could not survive. Alexaposs dad, who attended the inquest, said that he had wanted to place a permanent memorial to his son close to where he drowned. He added that Alexaposs colleagues have raised the money to install a bench in Stanley Park. After Alexaposs death his boss at C Fresh posted online: Alex was truly an amazing young man. All his friends would agree that he was intelligent, hardworking, pleasant, caring and literally wouldn’t hurt a fly. He is a true hero drowned sacricing his le to help another. He was loved by all his work colleagues and we miss him terribly. Tragically taken at . My heart goes out to all his family.AGoFundMeset up after Alexaposs death raised £, to help pay for funeral costs.The Samaritans is available  you need to talk. You can contact them for free by calling  , email jo@samaritans.org or head to the website to find your nearest branch. You matter. title: man who weighed 26 stone
story: Man who weighed  stone and scoffed  Double Deckers weekly drops  stone in a yearTobie Vermeire, , admits he would have ‘eaten himself to death’he had not made changes to his lestyleFood addict Tobie Vermeire, from Malvern Hills, Worcester, had always struggled with his weight Image: @obeseboxer Kennedy NewsByLeonie Chao-Fong:,  Jan | commentsA -stone man who scoffed  Double Deckers every week until he was so obese he aposcouldnapost put his socks onapos has lost  stone in a year in a bid to become a professional boxer.Tobie Vermeire, , from Malvern Hills, Worcester, had always struggled with his weight but began to find himself eating a four-pack of the Cadburyaposs chocolate bars with lunch and sometimes more in the morning and evening.Each Double Decker contains g of sugar meaning Tobie was consuming a kilo of sugar a week just from the habit alone. For breakfast every morning, he would eat sausages, eggs and bacon for breakfast, two Dominoaposs pizzas for lunch and a Chinese takeaway for his dinner - along with more snacks. Wearing XXXL clothes and with a waist that stretched to  inches, Tobie - who was an insurance broker at the time - was left ‘shocked and embarrassed to discover his weight was  stone.He began his journey to change his lestyle in September , binning the daily fast food, chocolate and ice cream diet to focus on boxing.After just over a year, he has lost more than  stone and has set his sights on turning professional as a boxer by the end of the year. He admitted it was a tough journey and that he would have ‘eaten himself to death’he had not made the changes and shaken his addictions to ‘calories, grease, fast food’. Tobie said: “Iaposve always had a real issue with food. It was a comfort thing for me growing up and it continued through my adult le.  When I was , I was playing rugby at a reasonable level but whenever I got an injury and couldnapost play, I was still eating asI was training. I just got bigger and bigger. Around  I decided to focus on my career but this meant I let my health get even worse. I ballooned from  stone up to  stone. I couldnapost put my own socks on. As his weight grew, Tobie decided to dropdown the levels so he didn’t have to train as hard and could focus on his insurance broker job. He began to pay even less attention to his health and his daily diet saw him consuming up to , calories a day while he continued his desk job. He said: “I was a food addict. It was the only drive or pleasure in my le outside of working so food was my getaway. I was at work one day and they brought the scales out for everyone to check their weight. I thought I was going to be  stone and that I was just a few weeks off the weight I had been previously. When I stepped on them, I was  stone and I was just so embarrassed about how big I had become. I was wearing XXXL clothes and had a  inch waist so I was massive.I started to get really ill - I was fatigued, couldnapost get out of bed, constantly had headaches. I was tested for diabetes and thyroid problems but it turned out to be the physical signs of depression. In order to kick his addition to unhealthy foods and to lose weight, Tobie set about going cold turkey on his favourite foods. I had to treat it like a drug addiction and go teetotal on most of the foods Iaposd eaten before, so no chocolate, takeaways or crisps. I felt awful at first, really ill. I was having withdrawal symptoms for the first few weeks, which was me coming off the copious amounts of processed foods and chocolate Iaposd been used to. I was addicted to calories, grease, fast food, the whole lot. My diet was abysmal so I had to change. If I hadnapost, I think Iaposd have eaten myself to death. Iaposd like to think Iaposve added  to  years on to my le by reversing the years of destructive eating.” He said he turned to boxing because rugby wasn’t inspiring him anymore and he knew he had to try a new challenge. He said: “Iaposve always been a boxing fan and I decided I needed to set myself a goal that kept me on track. I decided to train to become a pro. “I looked for help from a few people but I realised I had to do it myself. Once Iaposd lost a little bit of weight and gained confidence, I joined a boxing gym and started working by myself on the heavy bags. It has just snowballed from there. Iaposve had a couple of amateur fights since covid restrictions have been loosened and Iaposve been sparring regularly with experienced pros.Tobie set up an Instagram and TikTok page to keep him accountable. “Iaposve never been happier,” he said.The only thing that I feel which is slightly negative is that I didnapost do it earlier. I feel bad that I let it get to the worst and didnapost change my le sooner. Itaposs been a huge year of change. Itaposs helped my mental health massively too. I left my job as an insurance broker to start selling motorbikes as Iaposve always loved them. I need to get some more fights under my belt before I can go pro as well as sorting some sponsorship for travel. ”I was meant to be fighting at the end of January but that has been delayed as I have had covid. Weaposre looking to get as many fights in as possible this season.Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Cadbury Ltd.Dominos PizzaFast foodIce creamMental healthChocolateWeight loss success stories" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: miracle baby born 17 weeks
story: Miracle baby born  weeks premature weighed same amount as a tin of beansBonnie Elizabeth Morgans weighed an astonishing Ib oz when she was born  weeks premature on September ,  - and could have been classed as a late miscarriage before doctors recognised a sign of leBonnies mum, Rachel Morgans, , said her daughter broke the record as the youngest gestation to survive at Leighton Hospital in Crewe Image: Rachel Morgans MEN MediaByDavid Houston:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsA aposmiracleapos baby was born weighing just Ib oz following her incredible premature birth. Bonnie Elizabeth Morgans weighed an astonishing Ib oz when she was born  weeks premature on September , . Bonnieaposs mum, Rachel Morgans, , said her daughter broke the record as the youngest gestation to survive at Leighton Hospital in Crewe at  weeks and one day.Rachel said the cut off at Leighton Hospital is  weeks, so Bonnie could have been classed as a late miscarriage, but doctors gave Bonnie a chance after she showed a apossign of leapos. Thankfully, Bonnie came home for the first time on January , and her mum has spoken to CheshireLive about her experience. Rachel said: At the end of May , I found out I was pregnant because I thought I had appendicitis, but I never did.Bonnie was a twin, and I had miscarried the twin, so thataposs what the problem was. Bonnie was a suspected ectopic pregnancy, so basically they thought she might have been in the entrance of the fallopian tube.After a few scans, they decided that Bonnie could be a viable pregnancy, so we went ahead with it. Weaposve had quite a bad pregnancy. We had lots of bleeding and stuff like that, mainly due to the miscarriage and all that going on. Then on the th September at . Bonnie arrived in this world after like an hour labour. It was a very short labour. In Leighton Hospital, the cut off is  weeks, so Bonnie would have been classed as a late miscarriage, but the doctors that were on that day, and the midwe, who Bonnieaposs gets her middle name from, decided they would give Bonnie a chance,she showed a sign of le, they would give her a chance.  Bonnie came out and cried. Because she cried they said she showed a fight for le, so they did and pushed for her and sheaposs here today. Rachel said it was a aposreliefapos when she and her husband Adam Morgans heard Bonnie cry, but that their thoughts then turned to what was next for the baby. She said: I just assumed that she would never survive to be honest. Iaposve had a premature baby before at  weeks, my eldest, and I thought that was bad enough when she was born at  weeks. So I think me and my husband, when the labour started, we just assumed that she would never survive and that she would be born stillborn. But when she cried it was a relief, but it was also a bit like aposOK, so what does this mean type of feeling, weaposve got something  to deal with nowapos. Bonnie has such a horrendous time because she was transferred to Arrowe Park Hospital because they canapost look after a baby at Bonnieaposs gestation at Leighton, it needs to have what is called a tertiary care unit.  So she had to go to Arrowe Park. They have kept her alive to this day, but sheaposs had two cardiac arrests, sheaposs had surgery at Liverpool Womenaposs Hospital because sheaposs got whataposs called ROP [retinopathy of prematurity], which is basically from the oxygen that sheaposs needed to survive has damaged her blood vessels in her eyes. So sheaposs had to have laser eye surgery. You name it, this kidaposs had it. Sheaposs had the works. Bonnie came home on Thursday eveningfor the first time since her birth in September. Rachel said: Sheaposs on oxygen at home, but sheaposs on very minimal oxygen. Even though sheaposs like a Ib oz baby, sheaposs very tiny still. She looks like a newborn baby now. Sheaposs got whataposs called chronic lung disease now because she needed such high respiratory support. So sheaposs going to have that probably for the rest of her le, but theyaposre hoping they can get her off oxygen by her first birthday. Up until sheaposs around seven, she will be seen by a lot of neonatal consultants and paediatricians just to make sure that she does meet her milestones andthereaposs anything they can do, they will intervene to help us, but other than that they canapost see why she wouldnapost live a normal le at the minute. Bonnieaposs two older siblings, -year-old Imogen and two-year-old Ralph, were excited to welcome their baby sister home. Rachel added: It was quite a shock to them because we didnapost tell them we were bringing Bonnie home. We just pretended that we were having a meeting at the hospital and we just came home with her. I think everybody was just a bit in shock. Ralph has been so excited. He wants to help do everything. I think for Imogen, because of her age, sheaposs aware of whataposs been happening during our time at Arrowe Park and things, so for her itaposs just a relief that itaposs over and we can all be back together again now because since September we havenapost all been as a family unit. title: more education breastfeeding help new
story: More education on breastfeeding will help new mums who suffer with nipple pain" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _Mother-breastfeeding-her-baby-son.jpg" width"" "" Breastfeeding levels in this ­country are way below idealImage: Getty ImagesopinionByMiriam Stoppard:,  Jan | commentsBreastfeeding levels in this ­country are way below ideal. No woman should feel coerced into breastfeedingshe doesn’t want to, but I’m in favour of making it as easy as possible for her to breastfeed her baby and for them to bond. One of the greatest deterrents for mums is nipple pain. More than seven out of  of first-time mothers report nipple and or breast pain in the first week after giving birth. And the most common cause is inadequate latching on, as described by medical ­practitioner Lisa H Amir and colleagues. Latching on refers to how the baby takes the breast into their mouth to suck, and unless a new mum is shown how to do this, it’s dficult for her to achieve a good latch.  Many new mums don’t understand that the whole nipple, including a lot of the areola, has to go in the baby’s mouth. If not, the baby ends up “chewing and chomping” on the nipple causing bruising and painful breaks in the skin. It’s excruciating when the baby suckles. No wonder a woman wants to stop. It’s worth notingthe pain is continuous it’s unlikely to be ­inadequate latching.  If nipple pain occurs only with breastfeeding, the diagnosis is more likely to be latching dficulty. Other conditions, however, can cause nipple pain during ­breastfeeding such as surgical scars or nipple piercings. Both very long nipples and “flat” or inverted nipples can be painful too. Conditions of the breast itself may contribute. Fullness and hardness of both breasts may indicate engorgement. Redness might signy a blocked duct mastitis . If swelling and redness is marked, and spreading across the breast chest, it’s cellulitis. With engorgement, both breasts are “full”, tender and tense. A blocked duct or mastitis can cause tenderness in a section of breast that may be swollen and hard. With mastitis, the breast might be inflamed, firm, and lumpy. It’s also possible to have allergic dermatitis caused by using a nipple cream.  There again there are conditions where breast pain, or the perception of breast pain, is unrelated to ­breastfeeding such as fibromyalgia and muscle pain. A baby’s so-called tongue-tie is sometimes quoted as a cause of nipple pain, but it rarely is because it rarely truly exists. This leads to many babies having unnecessary tongue-tie surgery. It’s easy to blame tongue-tie for inadequate latching but it’s rarely the cause and parents shouldn’t use it as an excuse for both nipple pain and poor feeding. Most “tongue-ties” ­disappear as the baby grows. title: my parents named ikea free
story: My parents named me Ikea - they got a free sofa but I got bulliedA new mum and dad were inspired by an advert from the Swedish furniture store so named their newborn baby Ikea, but the youngster grew up and wished theyd chosen something  with her father Bradley." content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _SWNS_IKEA_NAME_.jpg" width"" "" Jasmine Dagless was originally called Ikea, but she legally changed her name after being bullied Image: Jasmine Dagless   SWNSByJohn BettAudience WriterBen Turner:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments A young woman had to change her name as a child because she was being bullied for her real name - as her parents had named her Ikea.Jasmine Dagless, , was named Ikea at birth after her mum saw a TV advert for the Swedish furniture store while pregnant, and she thought it sounded right. But when she grew up, Jasmine was dubbed aposflat packapos by school bullies who would cruelly joke about her unusual name. Eventually, sheaposd had enough of the bullying and legally changed her name after putting up with the insults for decades. What do you think about the name Ikea  Let us know in the comments...Jasmine, who changed her name in , said: I used to get called flat pack quite a lot at primary school. The bullying really shocked me because young children donapost know about Ikea. I legally changed my name when I was in secondary school. Itaposs only legally that I get called Jasmine. My family still call me Ikea, or aposKeaapos for short. Jasmine, an NHS admin assistant, said that her mum agreed to the name change - despite the family enjoying perks from Ikea after her birth.She said: When I was younger my mum got a letter from Ikea that basically said we could get furniture and toys free of charge. I got a few toys and my mum got a sofa. Jasmine has now swapped her middle and first name around, so sheaposs legally called Jasmine Ikea Dagless.  For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newslettershere. And sheaposs stayed loyal to the store by furnishing her flat with a branded six-drawer commode - and is considering buying a built-in wardrobe from the store. Jasmine, from Norwich, said she is keen to visit her local Ikea on a sentimental trip. I went to Ikea when I was one or two but as an adult Iaposve never been - I really want to go. Her name was changed when she was aged .Do you have a story to share  Weaposd love to hear all about it. news uk-news new-maps-show-how-covid-"Coronavirus in numbers: A further , cases recordedByDave BurkeSenior News Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments Latest maps show how Covid cases have fallen across the UK since Christmas - amid hopes that the Omicron wave has now peaked.In the past seven days, more than , infections have been confirmed by the Department of Health, but this is a % drop compared to the previous week. Maps published at the start of the year show a sea of black as the highly infectious iant tore through the country.  But cases have dropped signicantly in all regions - although infections remain high in parts of Northern England and the Midlands. It comes as the Government announced Plan B measures are being lted and Health Secretary Sajid Javid said the country is moving into the next chapter in the battle with the virus.  The North West, Yorkshire and The Humber and the West Midlands are currently experiencing the highest infection rates. London, which was the epicentre of the Omicron outbreak in the build-up to Christmas, has seen cases drop dramatically, and now only the South West has a lower infection rate. Cases in each region currently stand at:Yorkshire and The Humber - ,. cases per , people West Midlands - ,. cases per , people South West - . cases per , people South East - . cases per , people North West - . cases per , people North East - , cases per , people London - . cases per , people East of England - . cases per , people East Midlands - . cases per , peopleOn January , the Department of Health announced , infections in  hours, but in less than four weeks that has dropped dramatically. Yesterday afternoon the Government said there had been , new cases on Saturday. Last week the Government said it was moving into the next chapter in the battle against Covid.Health Secretary Sajid Javid has said he is optimistic the legal requirement for people in England to self-isolate with Covid can be lted in the coming weeks. Mr Javid said the Government was approaching a decision point and that it would be guided by the data in coming to a judgment.The current legislation is expiring in March unless Parliament decides to renew it. As a Government we have to make a decision on that, he told the BBC Radio  Today programme.We will make it in the next few weeks but it will be guided by the data at the time. From what we are seeing at the moment, from the case numbers, hospitalisations, the direction we are travelling at the moment, I am optimistic but I donapost want to say exactly what will happen in March. But I do want to see a time as soon as we can to remove all remaining rules and restrictions around Covid because we do have to learn to live with this virus in the same way we have learned to live, for example, with the flu. A World Health Organisation chief earlier warned that Europe is only passing the halfway mark of the pandemic - and said Covid should not be likened to flu. The WHO says governments should not suggest to people that the data has suddenly changed or the virus has suddenly got incredibly weak.Dr David Nabarro, the WHOaposs special envoy for Covid-, said that the end was in sight but said that Europe was only passing the halfway mark in a marathon.Asked about remarks that Covid- should be treated like the flu, Dr Nabarro told Sky News: I keep wondering what the people who make these amazing predictions know that I and my colleagues in the World Health Organisation donapost know. You see, what people are seeing from around the world and reporting to the WHO is this is still a very, very dangerous virus, especially for people who have not been vaccinated and whoaposve not been exposed to it before. news uk-news prince-andrew-selling-m-ski-"Prince Andrew: Judge declares Giuffre case will go aheadByChristopher BucktinUnited States Editor:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan Lawyers have questioned the sale of Prince Andrewaposs £ million ski chalet, believing it may have been sold to shield it from his sex abuse accuser. The claim came as US experts cast doubt on reports the Duke of York was looking to offer an early £ million settlement to Virginia Giuffre. Earlier this month, it was revealed Andrew, , had found a buyer for his beloved Swiss retreat, and the purchase was proceeding. Undoubtedly the sale would help fund Andrewaposs mounting legal costs in his civil lawsuit with Ms Giuffre, who has filed a civil sexual abuse case against him in New York. But now, an attorney for Jeffrey Epsteinaposs victims has revealed the deal appears less about paying her off, more about preventing her from claiming on the Dukeaposs assets.  If Virginia gets a judgment against Andrew,this went all the way through to trial and she received a financial judgment in her favour, she could execute on any properties he has, the most likely being his ski chalet, said lawyer Spencer Kuvin. If Andrew had properties in any companion country that would abide by such jurisdiction of the US, she can execute on those properties. Asked whether Ms Giuffre could make a claim on Andrewaposs -room Royal Lodge home in Windsor Park, which he shares with his ex-we, Sarah Ferguson, Mr Kuvin said it could not be ruled but would be very very dficult. A diplomatic conversation would be needed to be had, but I imagine it would be unthinkable that it would come to that, he said. Mr Kuvin warned: If the Queen has transferred any property to him, anywhere throughout the entire world, they could try and execute on that propertysuccessful in foreign courts.  Due to US courts having no jurisdiction over the UK,Ms Giuffre were to win her case, she would need to apply in Europe or Britain to have any damages enforced. Despite Switzerlandaposs famous financial secrecy, the assets and proceeds of an inidual are not protected there under law. Giuffre could execute on the chaletshe obtained a civil attachment order. According to Yves Klein, an asset recovery lawyer from Geneva-based law firm Monfrini Bitton Klein he states Swiss law ensures items and valuables belonging to an accused or to a third party may be frozenit is expected that the items or assets will be used as evidence, will be used as security for procedural costs, monetary penalties, fines or costs, will have to be ed to the persons suffering harm or will have to be forfeited. Mr Kuvin described speculation the Prince was preparing to offer a £million settlement to Ms Giuffre to dismiss her lawsuit as premature.  He added: Any offers or speculation about offers at this point is very premature. My guess is that they fight this as long as they can and only settle at the last minutethey feel they must. Giuffre, , has sued Andrew using New Yorkaposs Child Victims Actthat allowed those abused to sue their attackers. In , lawmakers introduced a look-back window that gave victims of decades-old abuse two years to file civil claims by August , , eventhe statute of limitations had expired. The deadline for claims was later extended due to Covid by then New York Governor Andrew Cuomo. Mum-of-three Ms Giuffre, who lives in western Australia filed the lawsuit on August ,  - just five days before the window closed.  She claims in , she was trafficked by billionaire Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell to have sex with the Duke in London when she was , a minor in US law. Giuffre also alleges she was forced to have sex with the royal at Epsteinaposs home in New York and the US Virgin Islands. The Duke, , absolutely and categorically denies her allegations. She is suing Andrew for unspecied damages, which Mr Kuvin said could easily be in excess of £ millionshe is successful. Most of Andrewaposs wealth has been tied up in his multimillion-pound properties, including the ski chalet he bought eight years ago. Some £ million is accounted for by the Royal Lodge, once the home of the Queenaposs sister, Princess Margaret.  Although it is owned by the Crown Estate, the Duke splashed out a further £. million on its refurbishment when he and his family moved in, so he could expect afor his money. Previously, father-of-two Andrew was given Sunninghill House as a gt when he tied the knot with Fergie in . In , six years after the coupleaposs orce, he put the home up for sale but could not find a buyer for more than five years. The home was purchased in  by Timur Kulibayev, the son-in-law of the former president of Kazakhstan, for £. million, several million over the asking price. The Duke is reportedly still earning money from the Queen after being banned from carrying out royal duties.  However, he has reportedly been stripped of the £, in public funds he received each year that saw the taxpayer hand him millions of pounds over decades. Andrew stepped down from royal duties following his car crash BBC Newsnight interview in November  about his friendship with Epstein. He is reportedly receiving an income from the Duchy of Lancaster - a private estate owned by the Queen consisting of , hectares of land in the UK. It includes assets in Cheshire, Staffordshire, Derbyshire, Lincolnshire, Yorkshire, Lancashire and the Savoy Estate in London. The body earns Her Majesty around £ million a year. news uk-news princess-eugenies-cheeky-complaint-royal-"Royal Wedding ceremony highlights as Princess Eugenie marriesByZoe ForseyFeatures Editor:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments Itaposs hard to believe that itaposs been three years since Princess Eugenie announced we all had another royal wedding to look forward to after getting engaged to Jack Brooksbank.Ten months after posing for their official engagement snaps, the couple tied the knot at St Georgeaposs Chapel in Windsor in front of the royal family, friends and TV crews. It was certainly a day to remember, with a celebrity guest list, a stunning wedding dress and a decent amount of social media ban rule-breaking. The bride and groom couldnapost have looked more in love, beaming throughout the public part of the day - but a lip reader has revealed Eugenie wasnapost entirely happy about one thing her new groom did on the day.  When they were sitting side-by-side in St Georgeaposs Chapel listening to readings, Eugenie jokingly said to her new husband: Why arenapost you holding my hand  The Queenaposs granddaughter took the lead and coached Jack through the day, with a letime of royal experience meaning she knew exactly what the crowds wanted. The lipreader revealed that the royal bride initiated the coupleaposs tentative smooches outside the chapel, saying letaposs kiss in front of the cameras. Jack spoke openly about his nerves ahead of the wedding, telling the Daily Mail: Iaposll need to take a few minutes for myself before the speeches because Iaposm terried. Itaposs very exciting but Iaposm a little bit nervous. He overcame his nerves, however, to whisper beautul words to Princess Eugenie as she approached him at the altar. Experts revealed he said Oh, my heart when he saw his bride, before adding Oh break my heart.  And it wasnapost just Eugenie who made some interesting comments at the wedding, and the Queen left guests stunned with a hilarious joke. Pixie Geldof, who was lucky enough to get an invite, chatted about the celebrations during a podcast with fashion designer Henry Holland, What Were You Thinking  She said: I didn’t meet her but she was walking around saying stuff like, ‘Well, it’s great that I have a house big enough to hold all these guests’. She’s full LOL. She was being funny. She was like, ‘Welcome to my home’. Pixie also explained that she had a rather embarrassing moment during the day, which saw her trip over in front of a group of other guests. She said: I fell over at one point. Stacked it, but not on to the floor. And not drunk – hadn’t drunk. news uk-news queen-gone-private-bolthole-reflect-"The Queen arrives at her Sandringham residenceByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Jan | commentsThe Queen has headed to her private bolthole on the Sandringham estate to reflect after a traumatic  months, a royal expert has said. Yesterday, pictures showed H er Majesty making the emotional pilgrimage from Windsor Castle to Sandringham for a stay at the five-bedroom cottage Wood Farm. The cottage is where the late Prince Philip lived following his retirement from public le and is where the Queen and her beloved husband could relax together. Her trip comes just weeks after the Queen stripped her son Prince Andrew of his military titles and learned grandson Prince Harry was launching a legal battle against her government over his security. And speaking to the Mirror, royal biographer Robert Jobson, author of the book Prince Philip’s Century, explained it has long been a place of retreat for the Queen. He said: The Grade II-listed Wood Farm, located on a secluded part of the Queen’s Sandringham Estate looking out to sea, has long been a bolthole for the Queen and her late husband Prince Philip. It is where the Queen, Philip, and their four children went to relax for more than  years. And, of course, it is where Philip made his retirement home in his twilight years with the Queen’s blessing The Queen was known to cook and even do dishes while she was staying there. Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. It is now the place Her Majesty, now a widow, has chosen to go for a bit of privacy and reflection after a traumatic  months. With its simple furnishings and open fires, it is a lot less formal than le at Windsor, Buckingham Palace and even Balmoral, although it is spacious enough. When Philip was there, he didn’t stand on ceremony and servants didn’t wear the usual royal unorms.  Prince John, the youngest son of George V and Queen Mary who suffered from severe epilepsy and possibly autism, resided at Wood Farm from  until his death there in  and before Philip moved in, the younger royals too had several times held private parties at Wood Farm.The Queen usually spends the month of January and February at Sandringham - following Christmas - in order to mark the anniversary of her father George VIaposs death.He died at the estate in February  - and this is when the Queen officially became the monarch.  This year marks  years since George VIaposs death and Robert says it will be especially poignant as it is also the first year the Queen will face the milestone since Philipaposs death last April. He added: As has been tradition for many years, The Queen has travelled to her Norfolk estate at Sandringham every Christmas and usually stayed on until after the anniversary of her father King George VI’s death, on  February in  in Sandringham. Again, due to Covid protocols, she had to remain at Windsor Castle since the autumn – where she held muted celebrations with close family, including the Prince of Wales and the Duchess of Cornwall. This Ascension Day will officially mark  years as monarch following the untimely death of King at just . There will be no broadcast to the nation, for Her Majesty, who will be  in April, it will be a day in quiet, sombre reflection. Now without Prince Philip by her side, it will be even more poignant. title: scorned woman harassed married ex
story: Scorned woman harassed married ex and his new lover - the concierge at her luxury blockLaura Templar, , sent a barrage of texts and emails to her ex-boyfriend, married dad-of-two Patrick OConnor, and his new lover, Caroline Decleves, who worked as a concierge at Templars flashy apartment block in Shoreditch, LondonLaura Templar, , met her ex Patrick OConnor while he was on a construction job at her flashy Shoreditch apartment blockByCachella SmithRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Jan | comments A jealous girlfriend who discovered her ex was having an affair with the concierge at her apartment block spent six weeks harassing them, a court has heard. Laura Templar, , sent continuous emails and text messages to married father-of-two Patrick OaposConnor and his lover Caroline Decleves.She also swore at Mr OaposConnor as he headed to his office by Broadgate Tower in Bishopsgate in the City of London, Stratford Magistratesapos Court heard. Mr OaposConnor, a married man, became involved with Templar in March  when he was working as a construction worker at her luxury apartment block in Shoreditch. The affair was on and off for about a year before they split, with Templar later finding out that he had started another affair with Ms Decleves.  Margaret Bankole, prosecuting, said: Patrick OaposConnor is married and has two children. He worked in the same building where the defendant lives. The affair began in March  and lasted for two months. Then the affair was rekindled in March last year and ended the same month, which is when it is said the defendant began harassing him by constantly sending him messages, emails and text messages. She would also send text messages to his private phone number and his work phone number. He, on numerous occasions, told her she was harassing him and to stop messaging him. On one occasion she sent a text message when he dropped his we off at work stating that she knows he just dropped her off. At this point he was unaware how she would have known that. She purchased tickets to a work event he would be attending and he did not make her aware of that event. On  August at am, Patrick OaposConnor saw the defendant as he was walking into his office by Broadgate Tower.  They crossed paths. It is said the defendant shouted at him What are you still doing here  When are you going to f*** off. Youaposre a c***. Templar also shouted and swore at Mr OaposConnor in the street, on some occasions when he was briefing staff outside of work. Mr OaposConnor had an affair with his colleague Caroline Decleves who works as a concierge in the same building the defendant lives. The defendant began to harass her also, constantly sending emails, contacting her on ious numbers and shouting at her on the street. Templar, who works as an underwriter, told Mr OaposConnoraposs we about Miss Decleves and sent photos to him of his family and children. When Templar was interviewed by the police, she explained her behaviour as believing that she was owed answers, the court heard. Mrs Bankole explained: She said she was in shock as she really loved Patrick and she thought he wanted to be with her. She told the police that she asked him nicely to not stand outside where she lives however he continued to do so. She still sees them every day. When they see her they laugh and wave. Miss Decleves now no longer works in the building. Christopher Pickwick, defending, said: Miss Templar works from home quite often, she has had to see both parties on a regular daily basis knowing that they are seeing each other and that Mr OaposConnor had ended the relationship with her. She found it extremely dficult living in those circumstances. No doubtthey werenapost working so close to her she wouldnapost be in court today. Prior to Miss Templar being interviewed by the police the messaging stopped. Miss Templar in her words said aposI stopped of my own accord when I calmed downapos. Templar, of Bowl Court, Shoreditch, admitted two counts of harassment without violence between  July  and  August . She was given a  month conditional discharge along with a  month restraining order. Templar, who wept during the hearing, was also ordered to pay prosecution costs of £. District Judge John Law said: Obviously, it is a very sad day for you, at  years old to be in front of me having previous good character taken away from you by your guilty pleas. This was obviously an unfortunate and badly ended relationship. But you know that you took that too far in terms of what you did by continuing to contact and harass people who didnapost want to talk to you. Iaposm going to deal with this with a conditional discharge - one of the most lenient sentences I can give. news uk-news ted-bundys-weird-last-words-"Watch the chilling trailer for new Ted Bundy documentary on Amazon PrimeByVerity Sulway:,  Jan | commentsWhat makes someone become a cold-blooded killer  Are they born that way or did something happen in their lives to turn them into a monster In Ted Bundy aposs case, thataposs what scientists were desperate to discover - whether there was a biological indication that made him a depraved murderer who stole the lives of at least  young women in the late s.Bundy was a good-looking, well-spoken law student who even worked on a suicide prevention phone line. So few people suspected he was the one targeting his victims, raping them, killing them and dumping their bodies, often collecting several of their heads as sick trophies and performing sex acts on them after covering them in make-up.In one final sick insult to those he had murdered, he would oftento where he had abandoned the bodies and have sex with their corpses. Getthe newsyou want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. In a further gruesome confession, Bundy even admitted to eating parts of his victimsapos bodies so he could possess them and they would become part of him. The killer claimed he was addicted to murder, saying: You feel their last bit of breath leaving their body. You’re looking into their eyes. A person in that situation is God. Bundy was finally arrested, tried and sentenced to death aged , having confessed to  murders. On January , , the killer refused to eat any of his final meal - a standard-issue steak, eggs, hash browns and toast because he hadnapost picked anything.  He called his mother, Louise Bundy, who wasnapost present at the execution. It’s a circus and we didn’t feel the agony we would go through by going down there would compensate for a few minutes talking to Ted through the glass, she said. And he also felt that way too. Askedhe had any final words, Bundyaposs response was surprising. Hesitating, his voice quavering, he told his attorney Jim Coleman and Methodist minister Fred Lawrence: Jim and Fred, Iaposd like you to give my love to my family and friends.  The LA Times reported: With that, it was time. A last thick strap was pulled across Bundyaposs mouth and chin. The metal skullcap was bolted in place, its heavy black veil falling in front of the condemned manaposs face. Barton gave the go-ahead. An anonymous executioner pushed the button. Two thousand volts surged through the wires. Bundyaposs body tensed and his hands tightened into a clinch. A tiny puff of smoke lted from his right leg. Meanwhile, hundreds of revellers sang, danced and set off fireworks outside the prison, chanting Burn, Bundy, burn and cheering when his body was brought out in a hearse. Eleanor Rose, the mother of one of his victims, Denise Naslund, said: For everything he did to the girls - the bludgeoning, the strangulation, humiliating their bodies, torturing them - I feel that the electric chair is too good for him.  Following his death, scientists were determined to find out what had turned this seemingly upstanding citizen into a monster. Bundyaposs brain was removed and a series of experiments were carried out to determine why he had carried out his horric crimes. Some brain injuries have been linked to criminality by some researchers, and several serial killers have shared similar neurological profiles. Bundy had told the detective who was instrumental in bringing him to justice that when he felt the urge to rape and kill, it was like a chemical tidal wave washing through his brain which he compared to being addicted to drugs. But when scientists examined Bundyaposs brain, it was found to be totally normal, with no legions, injuries or deformities. When he was alive, examinations by experts suggested he may have had a multiple personality disorder, been a sociopath, a narcissist and exhibited poor judgement and manipulative behaviour. Dorothy Otnow Lewis, a professor of psychiatry at the New York University School of Medicine and an authority on violent behaviour, said a prison guard told her Bundy appeared to transform into a dferent person in front of his eyes. He said, aposHe became weird on me.apos He did a metamorphosis, a body and facial change, and he felt there was almost an odour emitting from him, she recalled. He said, aposAlmost a complete change of personality... that was the day I was afraid of him.apos Do you have a story to share  Email webfeatures@trinitymirror Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Ted Bundy" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: toddlers viral infection turned out
story: Toddlers viral infection turned out to be cancer after mum found lump on his stomachDoctors initially suspected Jamie was suffering from a viral infection because his glands were swollen, but he was eventually diagnosed with cancerDoctors initially suspected Jamie was suffering from a viral infection Image: Family handoutByCharlotte Hadfield:,  Jan | commentsThe family of a toddler whose kidney cancer was mistaken for a “viral infection” has shared their experience of being delivered the devastating news. Little Jamie Clarke was rushed to Alder Hey Children’s Hospital earlier this year after his mum, -year-old Ashley Hughes, discovered a lump on the side of his stomach. Doctors initially suspected the two-year-old was suffering from a viral infection because his glands were swollen but he was taken back to the hospital by his dad Jamie, , the following day. Nan Angela Daniels, , from Kensington, said Jamie’s dad noticed this lump again and “wasnapost happy” so he took him back to Alder Hey.They said it was constipation and again it could be his glands,” she told the Liverpool Echo. “Ashley brought Jamie to my house on Sunday and he didnapost look himself. He was very grey and white, he wasnapost sitting properly in his pram and he couldnapost really walk. Angela said Jamieaposs grandad Andrew was also concerned after seeing the lump, so took him back to Alder Hey. After undergoing blood tests, the family was told Jamie had anaemia and he was kept in hospital overnight. The results of further tests revealed the two-year-old had a tumour that was cm by cm in size, as well as polycystic cysts on his kidneys. They didnapost knowit was benign or cancerous at this point,” Angela said. Due to the amount of cysts on his kidneys, she said doctors were concerned that a biopsy could cause them to burst. So on January , he underwent an eight hour operation to remove the tumour and kidney. Doctors told Jamieaposs family the devastating news he had a Wilms tumour - a type of kidney cancer that primarily affects children. Angela said: It was horrible. We always thought the worst. We knew that it was something bad but we didnapost realise how bad it was. He doesnapost understand whataposs going on, I think thataposs the hardest part. Heaposs got a good support network around him he really has. I think Ashley is still in shock and still quite numb. The operation was successful in removing the tumour but Jamie must now undergo six months of chemotherapy and radiotherapy at Alder Hey and the Clatterbridge Cancer Centre in Wirral.Angela has set up aGofundme pagein the hope of raising enough money to take Jamie on a day out or on holiday once he has finished his treatment.She hopes sharing Jamieaposs story will help to raise awareness of cancer in children and encourage others to always go with your gut instinct and not be afraid to go back to the doctorsyou are concerned. In a message on the Gofundme page, Angela said: We thought we would try this to help us give our baby a day he deserves. He is our true super hero and I wish no one will ever have to go through what we all have been through.
